quoteFirst: 0 |            | 7 | 6 m   |  13.0 | S 2        | Fair. Cloudy afternoon. | 3 a   |  24.0 |            |
quoteLast: it began |       |       |            | to rain, and continued till late |       |       |            | at night. 8 | 7 m   |   9.0 | N W 3      | Flying clouds.
title: Travels into North America, Volume 2 (of 3)
author: Kalm, Pehr, 1716-1779; Forster, Johann Reinhold, 1729-1798 [Translator]

quoteLast: they reached the southern boundary of the pine forest. The upward slope of the ground was so steep that the forest spread in tiers over the lower ramifications of the range, and the mountain summits came into view just as the sun was sinking behind the lesser chains which cut the western horizon.
title: Their island home
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Murphy, H. C. (Henry Cruse), 1886-1931 [Illustrator]; Wyss, Johann David, 1743-1818 [Other]; Metcalfe, Cranstoun, 1866-1939 [Translator]

quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , and we were all wet to the skin. The night was very dark, and the road, though they called it a 'pike,' was one of the worst imaginable; it wound 'round and round,'--
title: The Continental Monthly, Vol. 1, No. 3, March, 1862
author: Various

quoteFirst: that is to say a true and worthy German, an evangelical Christian, something more, in short, than a man! An angelic soul, always turned toward the good, serene, pious, and ready for action; he had come to live in a room next to mine in Professor Grunler’s house; we loved each other, upheld each other in our efforts, and, well or ill, bore our good or evil fortune in common. On this last spring evening, after having worked in his room and having strengthened ourselves anew to resist all the torments of life and to advance towards the aim that we desired to attain; we went,
quoteLast: , to the baths of Redwitz. A very black storm was rising in the sky, but only as yet appeared on the horizon. E., who was with us, proposed to go home, but Dittmar persisted, saying that the canal was but a few steps away.
title: Celebrated Crimes (Complete)
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870

quoteFirst: The weather was cloudy, but the cold had moderated, and the wind was North-West.  We were enabled to employ the sail during part of the day, and encamped at
quoteLast: .  We killed eleven old geese and forty young ones which had just begun to fly.  The English chief was very much irritated against one of his young men: that jealousy occasioned this uneasiness, and that it was not without very sufficient cause, was all I could discover.
title: Voyages from Montreal Through the Continent of North America to the Frozen and Pacific Oceans in 1789 and 1793. Vol. I
author: Mackenzie, Alexander, 1764-1820

quoteFirst: _June 6._ Yesterday at 4 a Clock in the Afternoon we spied a Sail, and at the same time saw the Land, the _Dutchess_ being a Mile a Head, gave chase first, we followed, and
quoteLast: the _Dutchess_ took her; we immediately sent our Boat aboard, and took out some of the Prisoners. She was a Vessel of about 90 Tun, bound from _Panama_ to _Guiaquil_, call’d the St. _Thomas de Villa nova_ and St.
title: A Cruising Voyage Around the World
author: Rogers, Woodes, -1732; Manwaring, G. E. (George Ernest), 1882-1939 [Annotator]

quoteLast: , but there was no sign of the baggage cart that night, and the Commandant (who had ridden out to meet us and then dined with us) was anxious, because only one trooper had been left with it, so he sent some more men out to meet them.
title: A Nurse's Life in War and Peace
author: Laurence, E. C. (Eleanor Constance); Treves, Frederick, 1853-1923 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: that is to say a true and worthy German, an evangelical Christian, something more, in short, than a man! An angelic soul, always turned toward the good, serene, pious, and ready for action; he had come to live in a room next to mine in Professor Grunler’s house; we loved each other, upheld each other in our efforts, and, well or ill, bare our good or evil fortune in common. On this last spring evening, after having worked in his room and having strengthened ourselves anew to resist all the torments of life and to advance towards the aim that we desired to attain; we went,
quoteLast: , to the baths of Redwitz. A very black storm was rising in the sky, but only as yet appeared on the horizon. E., who was with us, proposed to go home, but Dittmar persisted, saying that the canal was but a few steps away.
title:
Karl Ludwig Sand

quoteTime: About seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: we halted at a very convenient house on the roadside; got beds and supper; and at daylight recommenced our walk. We were now on the high road to Reichenhall, the last Bavarian town we should have to pass.
title: My adventures during the late war
author: O'Brien, Donat Henchy, 1785-1857; Oman, Charles, 1860-1946 [Editor]

quoteFirst: From that moment every one that showed his face in the street was shot. And the artillery meanwhile kept up vigorous work, so that at
quoteTime: about seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: , when the brigade advanced to rescue us, I could report ‘Saint-Dié has been emptied of all enemies.’
title:
Horrors and Atrocities of the Great War
Including the Tragic Destruction of the Lusitania
author: Marshall, Logan, 1884-1937; Gibbs, Philip, 1877-1962 [Contributor]; Parker, Gilbert, 1862-1932 [Contributor]; Thompson, Vance, 1863-1925 [Contributor]
